awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Computer Aided Design and Simulation Software for Origami
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable widespread adoption of origami design principles in industry to create manufacturing efficiencies and promote technological innovation.  Origami-inspired engineering has applications across virtually all Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields, yet existing computer-aided design (CAD) tools are extremely limited in their ability to model folded geometries. This Phase I project and subsequent commercialization effort will fill a gap in the market by creating powerful and user-friendly software to model folding, with target customers spanning a broad range of industries: product design, architecture, packaging, papercraft, education, manufacturing, and materials engineering. Academic publications resulting from the research and development conducted during this project will advance fundamental knowledge of the mathematics of folding. Furthermore, this work seeks to create positive educational impacts through ongoing collaborations with K-12 STEM educators to create engaging curricula in geometry, digital design, and manufacturing through papercraft.

This SBIR Phase I project will create an intelligent software system that facilitates the design and simulation of folded geometries via powerful origami editing techniques grounded in fundamental research. The Phase I research and development builds on the team’s prior work on origami design algorithms and efficient origami simulation methods to establish a novel design framework that supports intuitive editing of folded geometry by novice users. A particular focus of the project is the under-explored domain of curved crease origami, which promises new opportunities for high-performance materials engineering and expressive design.  Phase I research studies will investigate key open research problems underpinning the CAD system; this work will establish efficient methods and mathematical bounds for critical origami design algorithms to be implemented by the software system. Primary technical hurdles of the Phase I project include: architecting a novel constraint management system to support interactive editing of origami designs, establishing novel computational design algorithms for curved crease origami, and developing core data structures and geometry processing methods to be used by the CAD system. Throughout Phase I, the team will work with customers and strategic partners to identify specific use cases of folding in key vertical markets, develop a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) software application, and evaluate technical progress in terms of its commercial potential.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Though typically associated with folded paper, origami has broad applications in manufacturing as a scalable method for creating 3D objects from flat materials. Industrial applications of origami include packaging design, architectural facades, sheet metal fabrication, and deployable mechanisms in airbags and spacecraft. Folded materials exhibit exotic mechanical properties including multistability, negative Poisson's ratio, and programmable stiffness. The under-explored domain of curved crease origami promises new opportunities for high-performance materials engineering and expressive design. While the academic field of computational origami has undergone significant progress in recent decades, engineers and designers in industry lack adequate computer-aided design (CAD) tools to incorporate novel folding techniques into their professional practice.

During this Phase I SBIR project, Form Finding Studio developed novel CAD software for designing folding geometry, based on the design principles of origami. This work included developing a parametric design architecture, origami-inspired design algorithms, and custom data structures underpinning our software system, and working with potential customers across industries to validate the utility of these technologies. Our CAD tool uses real-time visual feedback to empower users of any skill level to build up design complexity through intuitive point and click interactions -- bringing advanced domains of origami design to a broad user base for the first time. The resulting browser-based application, currently in private beta testing (more at packcad.com), is initially focused on serving the packaging industry. In the process, we've developed five open-source software libraries, with plans to release four more, to help build a stronger community around browser-based mathematical and scientific computing.

A key focus of this Phase I project was the development of novel curved crease design algorithms, which will create new opportunities for innovation in engineering, manufacturing, art, and design. Our collaboration with the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (a subawardee on the Phase I project) supported the doctoral work of Klara Mundilova and her 2024 dissertation "Gluing and Creasing Paper along Curves: Computational Methods for Analysis and Design."

The PI presented developments from the Phase I project at OrigamiUSA's FoldFest, a global conference of educators, artists, and researchers. Her talk, titled "3D Origami Simulation and Design," introduced new methods for simulating origami to better capture the subtle bending behavior of paper and other thin materials that can occur as an origami model folds. As we continue to develop our technology, we will explore additional opportunities for this work to support K-12 STEM education, academic research, and public engagement with science and technology.

 

Websites:

  • https://packcad.com - product information and sign up for our beta testing program.

Open source software libraries advanced during Phase I award:

  • gpu-io is a parallel computing library for WebGL with broad applications for gpu computing, simulation methods, and graphics on the web, written by the PI: https://www.npmjs.com/package/gpu-io

New open source software libraries created during Phase I award:

  • msh-parser is a finite element .msh format loader and parser for the browser and Nodejs, written by the PI: https://www.npmjs.com/package/msh-parser

  • @amandaghassaei/stl-parser is a standalone module for loading and parsing binary/ASCII STL 3D files in the browser and Nodejs, written by the PI: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@amandaghassaei/stl-parser

  • @amandaghassaei/vector-math is a 2D/3D vector math library written by the PI: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@amandaghassaei/vector-math

  • @amandaghassaei/event-dispatcher is a parent class to support custom event listeners on TypeScript classes, written by the PI: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@amandaghassaei/event-dispatcher

Invited talks:

  • Amanda Ghassaei. "3D Origami Simulation and Design." OrigamiUSA FoldFest Conference. April, 2024. https://origamiusa.org/foldfest2024-spring

Theses/Dissertations:

  • Klara Mundilova. "Gluing and Creasing Paper along Curves: Computational Methods for Analysis and Design." PhD Dissertation. Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 2024.

 


Last Modified: 09/20/2024
Modified by: Amanda Ghassaei

Image
  • Example workflow for designing a custom box with curved folds in our novel 3D design framework, with each step showing the design's folded (top) and unfolded (bottom) geometry.
    Form Finding Studio LLC
    Copyrighted
    Amanda Ghassaei
    3D workflow for designing box with curved folds

gpu-io is a parallel computing library for WebGL with broad applications for gpu computing, simulation methods, and graphics on the web, written by the PI: https://www.npmjs.com/package/gpu-io
